docs.lead_paragraph: Many voters say they doubt that Bob Dole can fulfill his pledge to cut taxes while still balancing the budget, but his economic plan makes another promise that could prove even more difficult to keep: to improve the nation's growth capacity to 3.5 percent a year from its current level of less than 2.5 percent. No other Presidential candidate has ever put so specific a number on his aspirations for growth, never mind one that economists characterize as anything from highly ambitious to totally unrealistic.

headline.main: Dole's Plan for Economy Could Be Hard to Fulfill

docs.abstract: Many voters say they doubt Bob Dole could fulfill his promise to cut taxes and balance Federal budget, but economists are even more skeptical about his pledge to raise economic growth level to 3.5 percent, from curent level of less than 2.5 percent; economists believe American economy cannot now grow much faster than 2.5 percent without igniting inflation (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: In a South Lawn ceremony filled with both celebration and the ghosts of unmet goals, President Clinton signed a bill today to expand access to health insurance. And though the bill falls far short of his hope of insuring all Americans, he called it ''a long step toward the kind of health care reform our nation needs.'' Mr. Clinton used the occasion to declare a partial vindication for his and Hillary Rodham Clinton's own failed efforts to overhaul the health insurance system, saying the bill shows what can happen ''when we cross party lines and put the interests of the American people first.''

headline.main: Clinton Signs Bill to Give Portability In Insurance

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton signs bill to expand access to health insurance; says bill is long step toward kind of health care reform nation needs; photo of Clinton with bill's sponsors, Sens Edward M Kennedy and Nancy Landon Kassebaum (M)

headline.main: President Signs Health Insurance Bill, With Bow to His Wife

docs.lead_paragraph: Last January, Caren Brown, an effervescent woman, got the bad news that many people are hearing in this age of downsizing: she was being laid off from her job transporting patients at Long Island Jewish Hospital's psychiatric wing in Queens. But thanks to an aggressive effort by her union to deal with the layoffs brought on by the expansion of managed care, her tale will have a happy ending.

headline.main: Horse-Trading by a Hospital Union Is Sidestepping the Brunt of Downsizing

docs.abstract: National Health and Human Service Employees Union Pres Dennis Rivera, faced with radical revamping of health-care industry, has won his members job security and other protections that are envy of many other union leaders, and in view of labor experts, can serve as model for minimizing pain of downsizing; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In a move that would showcase one of his familiar family issues, President Clinton is expected to announce as early as Friday the final approval of Federal regulations cracking down on the marketing and sale of cigarettes to young people, White House officials said today. The new regulations would give the Food and Drug Administration significant new powers to regulate tobacco and would pose the biggest Government challenge to cigarette manufacturers since the 1964 Surgeon General's report that linked smoking to lung cancer.

headline.main: Clinton Set to Approve Curbs On Cigarette Sales to Youths

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton will announce final approval of Federal regulations that would give Food and Drug Administration new power to crack down on marketing and sale of cigarettes to young people; new regulations would pose biggest Govt challenge to cigarette manufacturers since 1964, when Surgeon General's report linked smoking to lung cancer; completion of yearlong rule-making process offers Clinton another opportunity to highlight his stand against smoking by teen-agers and gives him opportunity to burnish aura of leadership immediately prior to start of Democratic National Convention in Chicago (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Dow Falls 31.44 Points, As Tobacco Shares Skid The Dow Jones industrial average fell 31.44 points, closing at 5,689.82, hurt by rising interest rates and a slide in tobacco shares, notably Philip Morris, which fell $3.875, to $87.625. Several states joined suits against tobacco companies, while the White House planned to announce new regulations governing cigarette sales to minors. Broader indexes were mostly lower, but the Nasdaq composite index rebounded late in the day to close at 1,126.84, up 2.17, despite a skid by software stocks. $(Page D6.$) Tobacco Rules Set to Be Announced President Clinton is expected, as early as Friday, to announce final approval of Federal regulations cracking down on the marketing and sales of cigarettes to young people. The new rules would be the biggest government challenge to cigarette manufacturers since the 1964 Surgeon General's report that linked smoking to cancer. $(A1.$) Oil Companies Pay for Protection As guerrillas in Colombia increase their attacks on oil exploration and drilling sites, foreign oil companies, including British Petroleum and Occidental Petroleum, are beginning to pay millions of dollars directly to the Colombian military to deploy its best-trained officers and soldiers for protection. $(A1.$) Prostate Drug Called Ineffective A study said that Proscar, a prostate medication made by Merck, was no more effective than a placebo for most patients, while Hytrin, produced by Abbott Laboratories, significantly eased discomfort. Merck replied that five earlier studies had shown Proscar's effectiveness. $(A18.$) Clinton Signs Health Care Bill The President signed a bill to expand access to health insurance, calling it ''a long step toward the kind of health care reform our nation needs.'' $(B12.$) Fund to Invest in Java Products A leading venture-capital firm has formed a $100 million fund to invest in companies that will create software and related products based on the Java programming language developed by Sun Microsystems. $(D4.$) AT&T Agencies Get Assignments AT&T awarded key additional responsibilities to two of its four roster agencies, Young & Rubicam and FCB/Leber Katz Partners in a decision that could generate billings of at least $100 million. The agencies will be charged with enhancing the image of AT&T among consumers and businesses. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. $(D6.$) Monetary Union Worries Britons Financial executives and business economists in Britain are increasingly concerned about the consequences if the British choose not to join the European Monetary Union in 1999 and it goes into operation without them. $(D2.$) News Corporation Earnings Fall The News Corporation said that its net income fell 25.3 percent, to $807 million, in the year that ended on June 30, mainly because of higher newsprint costs and a loss on the sale of its educational books division. $(D4.$) Long Life for Mantle Memorabilia With his baseball cards fetching as much as $50,000, Mickey Mantle's popularity in the market for sports memorabilia has barely diminished in the year since his death. And a spate of new books, a reissue of all his baseball cards and strong sales of his memorabilia indicate a long future of popularity. A 1961 pinstriped Mantle flannel uniform is worth about $75,000. $(A1.$)

docs.lead_paragraph: With lawn mowed, shirts laundered and kitchen restocked after a 10-day trip, Steve Gunderson, Wisconsin Congressman, and Rob Morris, Virginia architect, treated themselves to a quiet dinner on their back porch, as crickets ushered in a tranquil twilight. It was a long way from San Diego, where the two attended the Republican National Convention last week and found themselves simultaneously at the center of press attention and on the outskirts of political influence for the same reason: their growing prominence as a gay couple, advocates for the notion that two men or two women can be a family.

headline.main: After a Less Than Grand Old Time
headline.kicker: AT HOME WITH: Rep. Steve Gunderson and Rob Morris

docs.abstract: Interview with Repr Steve Gunderson, an eight-term Wisconsin Republican who acknowledged his homosexuality in 1994, and Rob Morris, the Virginia architect and Democrat with whom he lives; they comment on their forthcoming book, House and Home, Gunderson's decision not to seek re-election and their hope for winning legal recognition of their union; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Lloyd's of London, the grande dame of the insurance business, is on the brink of getting a new lease on life. Next Wednesday, the large majority of its ''names'' -- the individuals who pledge all their assets to back the insurance policies sold at Lloyd's -- are expected to approve a plan that would restore the venerable British insurance market to solvency by handing off billions of dollars of liabilities to a newly formed reinsurance company called Equitas.

headline.main: But Questions Persist On Risks of Reinsurance
headline.kicker: The Financial Safety Net Is Almost Spread Beneath Lloyd's

docs.abstract: Lloyd's of London 'names,' individuals who pledge their assets to back insurance policies sold at Lloyds, are expected to approve plan to restore British insurance market to solvency by shifting billions of dollars of liabilities to Equitas, newly formed reinsurance firm; will pay up to $150,000 each to help capitalize Equitas and Lloyds will contribute some 3.2 billion pounds (almost $5 billion), freeing it of liability for claims arising from outstanding policies written before 1993; policyholders and insurance experts worry Equitas, even with $19.5 billion in reserves, will not have adequate resources; Lloyds chief executive Ron Sandler holds Equitas is 'extremely unlikely' to fail, interview; diagram; drawings; photo (L)

A1 DEEPENING RIFT OVER CHECHNYA The chasm between Russia's civilian and military leaders persisted as President Boris N. Yeltsin's national security adviser and his Defense Minister rebuked commanders in Chechnya for issuing ultimatums to the separatist rebels. A1 President Clinton called for a negotiated solution in Chechnya. A8 HORROR IN BELGIUM An unfolding story of the abductions of several young women has revived debate over how to deal with known sexual offenders, and how much freedom they should have after serving sentences. A3 REGRET FOR APARTHEID South Africa's former President, F. W. de Klerk, formally apologized for the pain and suffering caused by apartheid policies, but said he never authorized atrocities himself. A5 BOSNIA'S PROBLEMATIC ELECTION The dilemma Bosnian voters face going into the Sept. 14 election -- to vote where they are, or where they lived before forced from their homes -- is highlighting contradictions in the peace plan. A12 Opposing factions from Burundi briefed the United Nations. A7 French officials met with illegal immigrants from Africa. A11 Germany charged three men with illicit sales to Libya. A13 Cuandixia Journal: An old Chinese village bypassed by the new. A4 National A18-22, B10-14 CHEMICAL WEAPONS DETECTED In a new report, the Pentagon is acknowledging that chemical weapons were detected as many as seven times near thousands of American troops during the first week of the 1991 war in the Persian Gulf. A1 DOCTRINE BRINGS DISPUTE After 25 years in the pulpit, a Michigan minister is under attack because he has said Jews, Muslims and members of other religions may be as likely as Christians to enter heaven. A1 TOBACCO MOVE EXPECTED President Clinton is expected to announce final approval of Federal regulations that would give the Food and Drug Administration new power to crack down on the sale of cigarettes to young people. A1 THE NEW JERSEY SCRIPT The story line calls for a Republican who is behind in the polls to promise a big income tax cut then come from behind to beat the Democratic incumbent. It was followed by Christine Todd Whitman's campaign for governor in 1993 and Bob Dole is hoping formula work for him in the Presidential election. B10 THE CAPITAL GAINS DEBATE In addition to pushing a big income tax cut, Bob Dole is reviving questions about the capital gains tax, which has been hotly debated since a Democratic Congress increased the rate in 1986. B10 BATTLE OVER DRUG-USE REPORT Democrats were defensive about a new report showing a sharp rise in drug use by teen-agers, while Republicans attacked the Administration and experts cautioned that national policy possibly had little to do with the jump. B11 CLINTON SIGNS HEALTH BILL Calling it ''a long step toward the kind of health care reform our nation needs,'' President Clinton signed a bill expanding access to health insurance. B12 ONE DRUG FAILS IN COMPARISON A direct comparison of two drugs commonly prescribed for treating an enlarged prostate gland has found that one marketed by Merck & Company was no more effective that a dummy pill. A18 Metro Report B1-8 ACCUSED BEGINS HIS DEFENSE The man accused of masterminding the 1993 bombing of the World Trade Center stood before a Federal jury and defended himself against charges of plotting to blow up American jetliners in Asia. docs.lead_paragraph: New Jersey will wait until next month to join the list of states suing several large tobacco companies to recoup Medicaid costs related to smoking, a lawyer preparing the suit said yesterday. Michigan filed suit yesterday, becoming the 13th state to do so. Michael L. Testa, one of the lawyers hired in July for this case, did not say how much money New Jersey would seek. In New Jersey, the annual health care costs of smoking amount to about $2 billion, said John Shaffer, a spokesman for the Medical Society of New Jersey.
docs.abstract: New Jersey will wait until Sept to join list of states suing several large tobacco companies to recoup Medicaid costs related to smoking, Michael L Testa, lawyer preparing suit, says (New Jersey Daily Briefing) (S)
